Historically Catalonia, which already enjoys significant autonomy from Madrid, has been one of Spainâ€™s better-off regions and many of the local populace resent having to send taxes to the capital to help support poorer areas of the country. Catalonia accounts for one-fifth of Spainâ€™s economic output and has had no problem in attracting foreign investment. 
In November 2014, Catalans held a massive but symbolic regional independence vote, in defiance of the Spanish governmentâ€™s ban. An overwhelming majority of participants, 80 percent, said â€œyesâ€ to independence and secession from the central Spanish government in Madrid. 
Former Catalan leader Artur Mas, as well as former Vice-President Joana Ortega and former Education Minister Irene Rigau now all stand accused of civil disobedience for staging the vote in breach of a legal order from Madrid, which vowed to crush any attempt to stage a referendum.
